processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/BofA

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: BUY | PO: 150.00 EUR | Price: 109.75 EUR

Eiffage's H1'25 results were broadly in line (2% miss on EBIT, but in line on revenue and net income), with slightly weaker YoY FCF (vs demanding comps), but also with a positive trajectory in Contracting margins and Construction segment revenue inflecting positively in Q2. Management sounded confident on 2025 guidance. Near-term, macro and political considerations appear poised to dominate (ie the risk of rising French interest rates and uncertainty on corporate tax rates). However, a lot of risks seem priced in as the stock offers significant upside to our €150 PO as well as undemanding headline valuation metrics (10.8x 2025E P/E, IRR at 11.8%). We revise our estimates but make minimal changes to EPS. Retain Buy.

1/ German infra stimulus: the group expects to see incremental benefits over the medium- term; although not it in the very short- term; still, recent order intake in Germany has been strong, 2/ activity in France could see some support in the run up to the municipal elections in 2026, while Construction segment revenue growth should be positive in H2'25 3/ management said a modest working capital unwind is possible in FY'25, 4/ motorway traffic in the summer was \(+1\%\) vs 2024, 5/ no incremental commentary on the Getlink stake, 6/ management stated they consider the French corporate tax rate at 36% to be temporary in 2025 as per the wording of the law.

H1 group revenues were €11,928mn vs. BofAe at €11,954mn and VA consensus at €11,921mn. H1 EBIT came in at €1,006mn (vs. BofAe at €1,025mn and VA consensus at €1,029mn, ie 2% miss), with Concessions generating €845mn (vs. BofAe at €855mn and VA consensus at €847mn). Eiffage's Contracting segment reported EBIT at €241mn, vs. BofAe at €242mn and vs. VA consensus at €226mn. Eiffage's H1 net income reached €308mn (- 19% YoY, impacted by higher tax rates and share- based payments), vs. BofAe and consensus at €307mn. Order backlog is up 4% YoY to €29.5bn and - 1% QoQ. (vs €29.7bn in Q1). H1 FCF was a negative €91mn vs a +€148mn in H1'24.
\\* For full definitions of Qmethod measures, see page 8.

Our EUR150 Price Objective for Eiffage is based on a sum- of- the- parts methodology. We have applied 7.0x, 8.0x, 11.0x 2025E EV/EBITA multiples to Construction, Infrastructures, and Energy Systems divisions, respectively, in line with those of comparable listed pure- play comps. We value Eiffage stake in Eiffarie using a cash- flow- to- equity model with cost of equity set at \(7.65\%\) . Millau Viaduct and the A65 toll road are valued using DCFs with cost of equity at \(9.4\%\) , reflecting their higher leverage, We assume no terminal value for the concessions in our DCF. The PPP assets are valued at 1.0x P/BV multiples. We apply a 10pc NAV discount, higher than elsewhere in the sector due to reinvestment risk.

Upside risks: (1) traffic outperformance, (2) an increase in inflation driving tariffs higher, (3) faster- than- expected turnaround in Contracting leading to higher EBIT margins, (4) refinancing of more favourable terms than we currently expect.

Downside risks: (1) austerity measures driving down traffic and contracting order intake, (2) deterioration of working capital, (3) higher corporate taxes in France, (4) deflation, (5) an increase in real bond yield/interest rates.
